div.l: She wende the clerke hadde weryd a volupere
And wyth the staf she drewe aye nere and nere
And haue hyt this aleyn at the full
And smote the myllar on the pylled skull
And downe he goth and cryed harow I dye
The clerkes bete hym well and lete hym lye
And greyden hem and toke her hors anon
And eke her mele and on her way they gon
And at mylle dore yet they toke her cake
Of half a busshell flowur well y bake
Thus is the prowde myllar well y bete
And hath lost the gryndynge of the whete
And payd for the supper euerydell
Of aleyn and of Iohn that bete hym well
His wyf is swyued and his doughter als
Lo suche it is a myllar to be fals
And therto this prouerbe is sayd full soth
Hym dare not wene well that euyll doth
A gylour shall hym self begyled be
And god that syt hyghe in mageste
Saue all this companye grete and smale
Thus haue I quyt the myllar in my tale
Here endyth the reues tale
And begynneth the cokys prologe
THe coke of london whyle the reue spak
For Ioy he thouȝt he clawed hȳm on þᵉ bak
A ha quod he for cristys owne passyon
This myllar hath a sharpe conclusyon
Vpon his argument of herbegage
Well soth sayd salamon in his langage
Ne brynge not euery man in thy hous
For herberowyng by nyght is perlous
Well ought a man auysed for to be
Whom that he brynge in to his pryuyte
I pray to god so yeue me sorowe and care
Yf euer syth that I hyght hodge of ware
Herd I myllar bet y set a werke
He hadde a Iape of malyce in the derke
But god forbede that we stynten here
And therfore yf ye wouchesauf to here
A tale of me that am a poore man
I woll you tell as well as I can
A lytyll Iape that fell in our cyte
¶Our hoste answerde ⁊and sayd I graunt it the
Now telle on roger loke that it be good
For many a pasty hast thou lete blode
And many a Iacke of douer hast thou solde
That had be twyes hote and twyes colde
Of many a pylgrym hast thou cristys curs
For of thy persely yet fare they the wors
That they haue eten wyth the stubbed goos
For in thy shop is many a flye loos
Now tell on gentyll roger by thy name
But I praye the be not wroth for game
A man may say full soth in game and play
¶Thou sayst soth sayd roger by my faye
But soth play quade play as þᵉ flemyng sayth
And therfore harry bally by thy fayth
Be thou not wroth ar we departen here
Though that my tale be of an hostyllere
But netheles I woll not telle it yet
But or we depart ywis thou shalt be quyt
And therwyth all he lough and made chere
And sayd his tale as ye shall after here
Here endyth the cokys prologe
And here begynneth his tale
